Topic: Draw reversible and irreversible changes (ice melting vs. egg cooking)
Evidence Statements: The student can draw and label a picture showing a material before it is heated or cooled, such as an ice cube or raw egg.
The student can draw and label what happens to the material after it is heated or cooled, like ice turning into water or an egg being cooked.
The student can illustrate whether the change can be reversed by showing reversible changes like water turning back into ice.
The student can illustrate changes that cannot be reversed, like a cooked egg not turning back into a raw egg.
The student can use evidence from their drawings to create an argument explaining why some changes are reversible and others are not.
